definitions.definition: to remove or reduce an unpleasant feeling or pain

examples.text: to relieve the symptoms of a cold
Being able to tell the truth at last seemed to relieve her.
They try to relieve the symptoms of depression by drinking.
Don't resort to alcohol to relieve stress.
Take painkillers and hot drinks to relieve the symptoms.

definitions.definition: to make a problem less serious

examples.text: Aid workers called for further effort from governments to relieve the famine.

definitions.definition: to make something less boring, especially by introducing something different

examples.text: We played cards to relieve the boredom of the long wait.
The black and white pattern is relieved by tiny coloured flowers.

definitions.definition: to replace somebody at the end of their period of duty

examples.text: You'll be relieved at six o'clock.

definitions.definition: to free a town, etc. from an enemy army that has surrounded it
a polite way of referring to going to the toilet

examples.text: I had to relieve myself behind a bush.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French relever, from Latin relevare, from re- (expressing intensive force) + levare ‘raise’ (from levis ‘light’).
